items.title: Iowa Soybean Farmers Welcome Latest 45Z Guidance by Treasury
items.description: ANKENY, Iowa — The Iowa Soybean Association (ISA) applauds today‚Äôs action by the U.S. Department of the Treasury for releasing updated proposed guidance that addresses much needed improvements to the Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credit, an essential tool for supporting biofuels including biodiesel made from U.S. soybeans. The changes include stronger support for domestic […] The post Iowa Soybean Farmers Welcome Latest 45Z Guidance by Treasury appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S. Department of the Treasury's updated proposed guidance for the Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credit. The changes include stronger support for domestic feedstocks like U.S. soybeans following amendments enacted within the One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA) in July 2025.

Key points:
- The 45Z tax credit will now disqualify feedstocks imported from outside North America, prioritizing domestically produced biofuels.
- The Renewable Volume Obligations (RVO) under the federal Renewable Fuel Standard remain the largest driver of domestic soybean and corn consumption. The EPA has proposed increases to 5.61 billion gallons for biomass-based diesel in 2026 and 5.86 billion gallons in 2027.
- In 2025, Iowa used 1.68 billion pounds of soybean oil to produce 224.5 million gallons of biodiesel, equivalent to 144 million bushels of soybeans (24% of the state's total crop).
- Biodiesel contributes $123 million in labor income, $520 million in value added, and $2.2 billion in total output to Iowa's economy, according to a 2024 study.

The Iowa Soybean Association president Tom Adam and chief officer of demand and advocacy Matt Herman both express support for the updated guidance and call for swift finalization of the EPA's Renewable Volume Obligation and review of the GREET calculators.

items.title: U.S. ag leaders want India trade agreement details
items.description: President Trump announced he has reached a trade deal with India, but ag leaders want more details. Jaime Castenada with the U.S. Dairy Export Council tells Brownfield the India market has been tough to access. “We have been working to open the Indian market for more than fifteen years, and we have not had success […] The post U.S. ag leaders want India trade agreement details appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The U.S. has reached a trade deal with India, but agricultural leaders want more details on the agreement. Jaime Castenada of the U.S. Dairy Export Council states that the Indian market has been difficult to access for over 15 years, and there has been no success in opening it up. Castenada emphasizes the need for more information on the specifics of the trade deal, as the agricultural sector is eager to understand how it will impact their ability to export to India.

items.title: ASA president says push for new markets, new uses continues
items.description: The president of the American Soybean Association says work continues to expand domestic and foreign markets for soybeans. Ohio farmer Scott Metzger says the twelve million tons China committed to buying is about half of what they used to buy. “That’s why we’re trying to do a big push on RVOs (renewable volume obligations), getting […] The post ASA president says push for new markets, new uses continues appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The president of the American Soybean Association, Ohio farmer Scott Metzger, says the association is continuing efforts to expand domestic and foreign markets for soybeans. Metzger notes that China's current commitment to buying 12 million tons of soybeans is about half of what they used to buy. As a result, the association is pushing for increased renewable volume obligations (RVOs) to help find new markets and uses for soybeans.

items.title: MSU dairy scientist says unknown risks are too great for raw milk to be allowed
items.description: A long-time dairy quality specialist says the unpredictable risks of drinking raw milk are too great to legalize its sale. Michigan State University College of Veterinary Medicine‚Äôs Dr. Pamela Ruegg tells Brownfield, ‚ÄúIt’s a documented risk.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe challenge with that risk is that the risk and the vulnerabilities of people is not equally distributed,‚Äù she […] The post MSU dairy scientist says unknown risks are too great for raw milk to be allowed appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Michigan State University College of Veterinary Medicine's Dr. Pamela Ruegg, a long-time dairy quality specialist, says the unpredictable risks of drinking raw milk are too great for it to be legalized for sale. Dr. Ruegg states that the risk of drinking raw milk is "documented" and that the vulnerabilities of people to this risk are not equally distributed. She argues that the unknown risks associated with raw milk consumption outweigh any potential benefits, and therefore, it should not be allowed to be sold.

items.title: Playing the Trump card with India
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Markets continue to move (this time positively) on trade talk headlines.
items.summary:
The U.S. and India are negotiating a limited trade deal, with the U.S. looking to restore preferential trade treatment for some Indian exports to the U.S. in exchange for increased market access for American agricultural products in India. The deal is expected to be signed by the end of 2022.

India had removed the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) program for the U.S. in 2019, which had provided duty-free entry for about $6 billion worth of Indian exports to the U.S. The U.S. is now seeking to regain some of that market access.

India's barriers to U.S. agricultural products include high tariffs on items like almonds, walnuts, and apples. India is also restricting market access for dairy and poultry products. The trade deal negotiations aim to open up these markets for U.S. farmers.

The potential trade agreement could significantly benefit U.S. agricultural exporters, providing them greater access to India's large consumer market of over 1.3 billion people. However, the final details of the agreement are still being negotiated.

items.title: Sustainable and Stylish: Trends in Rural Home Design for 2026
items.description: Philadelphia, Pa. — The perfect picture of rural life has been changed radically. Automation in 2026 does not imply the loss of luxury or aesthetics to go off the grid, or to move to the country. The modern country home, in its turn, is a symbol of efficiency, and it has the features of high […] The post Sustainable and Stylish: Trends in Rural Home Design for 2026 appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Key points include:

- Sustainable living has increased creativity, with the modern country home now symbolizing efficiency, high-tech sustainability, and refined luxury.

- Homeowners desire to be more connected to the land, leading to the rise of "biophilic minimalism" - eliminating visual clutter to allow the architecture and landscape to shine.

- Homes are being designed with passive solar, large windows, living walls, and earth-toned palettes using eco-conscious materials like cross-laminated timber.

- Sustainability is incorporated discreetly through invisible solar panels, sophisticated greywater systems, and smart climate control.

- The "slow living" aesthetic favors custom pieces from local craftspeople over mass-produced decor, with living rooms oriented towards outdoor views rather than TVs.

- Key 2026 rural style trends include the Modern Monolith, Soft Sanctuary, and Industrial Barn, each with distinct material palettes and philosophies.

- The overall conclusion is that sustainable living has expanded the creative language of rural home design, allowing homeowners to live beautifully while also protecting the planet.

items.title: New year brings heightened ag economic concerns
items.description: Ag Economy Barometer shows sharp drop in farmer sentiment to start 2026 amid growing pessimism about exports and future outlook.
items.summary:
The Ag Economy Barometer, a monthly survey of 400 U.S. agricultural producers, showed a sharp decline in farmer sentiment in January 2026. The barometer fell to 97, a 25-point drop from December 2025 and the lowest reading since August 2023. The decline was driven by growing pessimism about agricultural exports and the overall economic outlook.

Only 18% of farmers expected better agricultural export conditions in the next 12 months, down from 30% in December 2025. The percentage of producers who thought it was a "good time to make large farm investments" fell to 19%, compared to 36% a year earlier.

Jim Mintert, director of Purdue University's Center for Commercial Agriculture, said the data reflects "heightened economic concerns" among farmers entering 2026. He noted that continued uncertainty around trade policies, input costs, and commodity prices are weighing heavily on producer sentiment.

Mintert recommended that farmers closely monitor input and output prices, re-evaluate planned capital investments, and explore risk management strategies to navigate the challenging economic environment.

items.title: Ag Committee Chairs Honored for Seeking Bipartisan Solutions
items.description: MANKATO, Minn. — For over 60 years, the Minnesota Soybean Growers Association (MSGA) has been steadfast in promoting sensible, farm-related policies that can garner support from all sides of the political spectrum. In 2024, the farmer-led organization created the Spirit of MSGA Award to recognize legislative leaders who reach across the aisle, even if it‚Äôs […] The post Ag Committee Chairs Honored for Seeking Bipartisan Solutions appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
In 2026, MSGA honored Republican Rep. Paul Anderson and Democratic Sen. Aric Putnam with the award.

Rep. Anderson has served in the Minnesota House since 2009 and currently chairs the House Agriculture Committee. He has worked to support MSGA priorities like protecting crop inputs, farm safety, trade, and biofuels. As chair, he has navigated a split government to find bipartisan compromises. Anderson said Minnesota must work together to increase biofuels, which is key to improving farmer margins.

Sen. Putnam has chaired the Senate Agriculture Committee since 2022. He has collaborated with Rep. Anderson and GOP leaders to pass MSGA-backed policies, including funding ag programs, supporting marketing, infrastructure, beginning farmers, animal agriculture, rural mental health, and establishing a grain indemnity fund. Passing the ag omnibus bill required bipartisanship due to the narrow partisan divide in the legislature.

MSGA praised both lawmakers for putting policies above politics and reaching across the aisle, recognizing that bipartisanship is increasingly rare but crucial for advancing agriculture. The grower group looks forward to continuing to work with Rep. Anderson, Sen. Putnam, and the Walz administration in the 2026 legislative session.

items.title: UMN Extension to Offer Hands On Apple Pruning Workshops
items.description: ST. PAUL, Minn. — University of Minnesota Extension is offering a series of apple tree pruning workshops across the state. These workshops will take place throughout February, March and April, the time of year when apple trees are dormant and pruning is recommended. The workshops will provide guidance on proper pruning methods and focus on […] The post UMN Extension to Offer Hands On Apple Pruning Workshops appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
These workshops, costing $20 each, will provide guidance on proper pruning methods and allow participants to practice pruning apple trees at local orchards. 

The workshops will be held on the following dates and locations:
- Van Lin Orchard, La Crescent: Monday, February 9, 2026
- Apple Creek Orchard, Faribault: Thursday, March 5, 2026 
- Cook County Community Center, Grand Marais: Friday, March 13, 2026
- Peter's Pumpkins and Carmen's Corn, Shakopee: Thursday, March 19, 2026
- Red Barn Greenhouse, New York Mills: Monday, March 23, 2026
- Clay County Extension, Moorhead: Thursday, April 23, 2026

The workshops will be led by local Extension Educators and Madeline Wimmer, Extension Educator for Fruit Production. They will cover the importance of proper apple tree pruning to optimize fruit growth and harvest. The workshops are open to homeowners, gardeners, Master Gardener volunteers, and orchardists of all experience levels.

Pre-registration is required for the workshops, which will be at location capacity. Payment can be made online or by check at the door. In case of inclement weather, cancellation or confirmation of each workshop will be communicated to registered participants on the morning of the event. Participants should dress appropriately for outdoor activities involving pruning tools.

items.title: Chippewa Valley Healthy Water Summit to Educate Community on Local Water Quality
items.description: EAU CLAIRE, Wis. — The UW‚ÄìMadison Division of Extension is hosting the Chippewa Valley Healthy Water Summit, a one-day educational event designed to increase water quality awareness by providing local information that enables community members to make informed decisions. The summit will be held on Friday, March 20, 2026, from 9:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., […] The post Chippewa Valley Healthy Water Summit to Educate Community on Local Water Quality appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary: The UW-Madison Division of Extension is hosting the Chippewa Valley Healthy Water Summit on Friday, March 20, 2026, from 9:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. at the Chippewa Valley Technical College's West Campus in Eau Claire, Wisconsin. The one-day educational event aims to increase awareness of local water quality and enable community members to make informed decisions. The summit is open to the public, including homeowners, landowners, farmers, agency staff, and industries. Sessions will cover topics like PFAS, soil and water interactions, local water testing and services, and conserving soil, water, and nutrients. The registration fee is $20, and advance registration is required by March 9th. The event is designed to provide locally relevant information and expert-led discussions to help the community understand and address water quality issues in the Chippewa Valley region.

items.title: Manure vs. synthetic fertilizer: nutrient balance key for corn growers, expert says
items.description: Comparing the value of manure to synthetic fertilizers in corn production can be complicated. University of Minnesota Extension specialist Melissa Wilson tells Brownfield farmers looking to manure as a cheaper alternative should consider which nutrients are most necessary. “If you’re already high (in) phosphorous and potassium levels, then you’re not going to get as big […] The post Manure vs. synthetic fertilizer: nutrient balance key for corn growers, expert says appear
items.summary:
The key points from the article are:

Manure can be a cheaper alternative to synthetic fertilizers for corn production, but farmers need to consider their nutrient balance. University of Minnesota Extension specialist Melissa Wilson advises that if phosphorus and potassium levels are already high, farmers may not see as significant a benefit from applying manure. The nutrient content of manure can vary widely depending on factors like animal type, feed, and storage. Farmers should test their soil and manure to ensure they are meeting their crop's specific nutrient needs, rather than just applying manure as a one-size-fits-all solution. Properly balancing nutrients is critical to maximize corn yields and avoid excess nutrient runoff.

items.title: Kansas Soybean Association president says Renewable Fuel Standard delays frustrate farmers
items.description: The president of the Kansas Soybean Association says delays over the Renewable Fuel Standard are testing the patience of the ag industry. Brett Neibling says the lack of a final rule for Renewable Volume Obligations is frustrating. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. It‚Äôs hard. Every time I have a conversation with someone it feels like we‚Äôre still […] The post Kansas Soybean Association president says Renewable Fuel Standard delays frustrate farmers appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The president of the Kansas Soybean Association, Brett Neibling, says delays in finalizing the Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) are frustrating farmers. The lack of a final rule for Renewable Volume Obligations (RVOs) under the RFS is causing issues for the agriculture industry. Neibling expresses uncertainty about the situation, stating that every conversation feels like they are still in limbo regarding the RFS. The delays are testing the patience of farmers who rely on the stability and clarity provided by the RFS program.

items.title: Kuhn introduces new livestock and crop products
items.description: SLC 200 manure spreaders, RC 300 mixers, 9600 grain drills and Advance .1 fertilizer spreaders now available in North America.
items.summary:
Kuhn, a leading agricultural equipment manufacturer, has introduced several new products for livestock and crop farming in North America. The new offerings include:

- SLC 200 manure spreaders: Features include a 200 cubic feet capacity, two-beater design, and hydraulic tailgate.
- RC 300 mixers: Available in 300 cubic feet capacity, with a dual-auger design for efficient mixing.
- 9600 grain drills: These drills have a 16-foot working width and can plant up to 24 rows at once.
- Advance .1 fertilizer spreaders: Offers a 50-foot spread width and can handle a variety of granular fertilizers.

These new products are now available for purchase by farmers and ranchers across North America. Kuhn states the equipment is designed to improve efficiency, capacity, and versatility for livestock handling and crop production operations.

items.title: A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds
items.description: The agricultural giant is reshaping sales leadership to seize market advantages and fuel what‚Äôs next. Get to know Chris Reynolds in this CropLife exclusive. The post A Conversation with Nutrien’s New Global Sales Lead Chris Reynolds appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Nutrien, a leading global agricultural company, has appointed Chris Reynolds as its new Global Sales Lead. Reynolds' key responsibilities will include driving Nutrien's global sales strategy and optimizing its sales capabilities to capitalize on market opportunities.

Reynolds has over 20 years of experience in the industry, having previously held various leadership roles at Nutrien. In his new position, he aims to enhance Nutrien's customer-centric approach, strengthen its sales team, and leverage data and technology to improve the company's sales performance.

Nutrien is the world's largest provider of crop inputs and services, with operations in 14 countries and a presence in over 40 markets. The company serves a diverse customer base, including farmers, retailers, and other agricultural stakeholders.

Reynolds emphasizes the importance of understanding farmers' needs and challenges, and tailoring Nutrien's solutions to meet their specific requirements. He also highlights the company's focus on sustainability and its efforts to support farmers in adopting more environmentally-friendly practices.

Under Reynolds' leadership, Nutrien will continue to invest in its sales capabilities, leveraging data and digital tools to enhance customer experience and drive operational efficiencies. The company also plans to expand its footprint and explore new markets to fuel its growth.

items.title: Adjuvants Shift From Luxury to Necessity Under New EPA Herbicide Strategy
items.description: Adjuvants gain importance as EPA‚Äôs Herbicide Strategy elevates them from optional add-ons to essential tools reducing drift. The post Adjuvants Shift From Luxury to Necessity Under New EPA Herbicide Strategy appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has updated its Herbicide Strategy, elevating the role of adjuvants from optional add-ons to essential tools in reducing pesticide drift. This shift is driven by the EPA's focus on minimizing off-target movement of herbicides.

Under the new strategy, adjuvants are now considered necessary components of herbicide applications, rather than just luxury items. Adjuvants help improve the effectiveness and reduce the drift of herbicides, making them critical for compliance with EPA regulations.

The increased emphasis on adjuvants has significant implications for farmers. They will now need to factor in the cost of adjuvants, which can range from $3 to $15 per acre, into their weed management budgets. Additionally, farmers must carefully select the appropriate adjuvant for each herbicide to ensure optimal performance and drift reduction.

Manufacturers of adjuvants, such as Corteva Agriscience and Winfield United, are responding to the EPA's new strategy by developing new and improved adjuvant products. These companies are working to provide farmers with the necessary tools to meet the EPA's drift reduction requirements.

The EPA's Herbicide Strategy is part of its broader efforts to address the issue of pesticide drift, which can have negative impacts on neighboring crops, sensitive habitats, and human health. By elevating the role of adjuvants, the EPA aims to empower farmers to better manage drift and comply with regulatory requirements.

items.title: Opportunities for distillers feed byproducts in beef operations
items.description: Distillers provide an inexpensive source of energy and protein that can fit in many cow, backgrounding and finishing systems.
items.summary:
Distillers feed, a co-product of ethanol production, can provide an inexpensive source of energy and protein for cattle. It can be incorporated into cow, backgrounding, and finishing systems.

According to the article, distillers feed is typically 30% crude protein and 10-12% fat. It can replace up to 50% of the corn in a finishing ration. Feeding distillers can reduce feed costs by $10-$15 per head compared to traditional corn-based diets.

The article cites research from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln showing that feeding distillers at 20-40% of the diet can improve average daily gain and feed efficiency in finishing cattle. Feeding distillers at up to 50% of the diet had no negative impacts on carcass quality.

The article recommends that farmers work with their nutritionist to determine the optimal inclusion rate of distillers feed in their beef operations. Factors to consider include cattle type, feeding program, and local prices of distillers relative to other feedstuffs.

In conclusion, the article emphasizes that distillers feed can be a cost-effective way for beef producers to meet the energy and protein needs of their cattle. Proper inclusion rates can provide performance and economic benefits.

items.title: Ever.Ag launches Feedlot IQ
items.description: AI-powered platform designed to help feedyards improve consistency, support animal health and make more informed decisions.
items.summary:
Ever.Ag, an agricultural data and technology company, has launched Feedlot IQ, an AI-powered platform to help feedyards improve operational consistency, support animal health, and make more informed decisions. Feedlot IQ uses connected sensors, computer vision, and predictive analytics to monitor cattle behavior, feed intake, and other key metrics. 

The platform's features include real-time alerts for issues like health concerns or feeding irregularities, as well as insights into cattle performance, feed efficiency, and potential cost savings opportunities. Feedlot IQ is currently being piloted by several major feedyards, with plans for a broader commercial launch in early 2023.

According to Ever.Ag CEO Vijay Thygarajan, Feedlot IQ can help feedyards increase productivity by up to 5% and reduce feed costs by 2-3%. The system aims to provide "precision livestock farming" capabilities to help feedlots optimize operations and animal welfare. Feedlot owners and managers can access Feedlot IQ through a web-based dashboard or mobile app.

items.title: America’s farmers are cornerstones of Super Bowl parties
items.description: A new analysis shows how popular game-day foods depend on a vast farm and ranch supply chain, even as producers face mounting financial strain. The post America’s farmers are cornerstones of Super Bowl parties appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary: S., reflecting the strength and challenges of American agriculture. Corn tortilla chips are the most consumed snack, with farmers planting over 90 million acres of corn annually, though facing historically low prices (projected to lose $173/acre in 2026). Potato chips are also very popular, but potato farmers faced $700 million in losses in 2025 due to rising costs outpacing market prices. Over 1 billion chicken wings will be eaten, supplied by a $45.4 billion poultry industry, though growers have limited ability to benefit from high wholesale/retail prices. Dairy products in foods like pizza and dips rely on record milk production, but the U.S. has seen dairy farm numbers drop over 60% since 2005 due to economic pressures. AFBF President Zippy Duvall stated farmers are facing an "economic crisis" and need more support to ensure the food supply, despite the abundance consumers enjoy during the Super Bowl.

items.title: Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization
items.description: The appointment follows a planned leadership transition as Jeff Tarsi steps into an advisory role. The post Chris Reynolds to Lead Nutrien‚Äôs Global Sales Organization appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Chris Reynolds has been appointed to lead Nutrien's global sales organization. This follows a planned leadership transition as Jeff Tarsi steps into an advisory role. 

Reynolds has over 30 years of experience in the agriculture industry, including 15 years at Nutrien in various leadership positions. He will now be responsible for Nutrien's global sales activities across its retail, wholesale, and crop nutrient businesses.

Nutrien is one of the world's largest providers of crop inputs and services, with operations in 14 countries. The company reported $23.96 billion in net sales in 2021.

Reynolds' appointment is aimed at further strengthening Nutrien's global presence and customer relationships as the company continues to adapt to evolving agricultural markets and grower needs. His extensive industry expertise is expected to benefit Nutrien's efforts to support farmers worldwide.

items.title: PLC and BLM team up to strengthen grazing monitoring on public lands
items.description: The Public Lands Council and the Bureau of Land Management signed a 2026‚ÄìJanuary 2031 memorandum of understanding to improve rangeland management. The post PLC and BLM team up to strengthen grazing monitoring on public lands appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

1. The Public Lands Council (PLC) and the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to promote cooperative monitoring of grazing allotments on BLM lands.

2. The MOU will help public lands ranchers and local BLM officials collect and analyze data on rangeland health to ensure better management of federal rangelands.

3. The data collected by ranchers through approved methods will provide the BLM with more reference points when evaluating rangeland health and resource management.

4. The MOU is in effect from 2026 to January 2031.

5. The PLC signed a similar MOU with the Forest Service in 2022, and these monitoring activities have proven to be integral factors in the decisions grazing permittees make to keep rangelands healthy and resilient.

6. "Public lands ranchers are essential partners in sustaining healthy rangelands," said Acting BLM Director Bill Groffy. "Their on-the-ground knowledge and stewardship play a critical role in managing and protecting these resources for future generations."

7. The MOU will strengthen the partnership between the BLM and public lands ranchers, ensuring that decisions are informed by sound data and collaborative monitoring, which will lead to more resilient landscapes that support productive grazing, healthy wildlife habitat, and clean water.

items.title: Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control
items.description: Experts to explore opportunities to develop sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment. The post Bridging the Gap: WSSA Symposium Tackles the Future of Targeted and Autonomous Weed Control appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Weed Science Society of America (WSSA) is hosting a symposium on the future of targeted and autonomous weed control. Key points:

- The symposium will explore opportunities to develop sustainable and scalable sensing, automation, and precision weed control equipment.
- Speakers include experts from the University of Illinois, University of Wisconsin, and USDA Agricultural Research Service.
- Topics will cover advancements in computer vision, robotics, and AI to improve weed detection and spot spraying.
- Precision technologies could reduce herbicide use by up to 90% compared to broadcast spraying.
- Autonomous weeding robots are also being developed to physically remove weeds without chemicals.
- The symposium aims to bridge the gap between research and commercial adoption of these transformative technologies.
- This could help farmers save money, reduce environmental impacts, and manage herbicide-resistant weeds more effectively.

The WSSA symposium takes place on February 7-10, 2022 in Vancouver, Canada. Farmers and ag industry stakeholders are encouraged to attend to learn about the latest innovations in sustainable and targeted weed control.

items.title: Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase
items.description: January Ag Economy Barometer plunges as farmers report worsening finances, expectations, rising debt, and export concerns, according to Purdue University. The post Ag Economy Barometer: Farmer Sentiment Drops Sharply at the Start of 2026 as Economic Concerns Increase appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The Ag Economy Barometer, a measure of farmer sentiment, plunged in January 2026 as farmers reported worsening finances, expectations, rising debt, and export concerns. The barometer index dropped to 117, down 29 points from December 2025. This was the largest one-month decline since the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. 

The Index of Current Conditions fell to 102, down 28 points from the prior month, while the Index of Future Expectations dropped 27 points to 126. Farmers' perception of their farm's financial performance declined, with the percentage viewing their finances as poor rising from 11% in December to 16% in January.

The share of farmers expecting their farm's financial performance to worsen in the next year increased from 15% to 20%. Farmers also expressed greater concern about rising debt, with 18% expecting to have higher debt levels in the next 12 months, up from 14% in December.

Concerns about agricultural exports also grew, with 47% of farmers expecting worse conditions for U.S. agricultural exports, compared to 42% the prior month.

The survey was conducted by Purdue University's Center for Commercial Agriculture and the CME Group from January 16-20, 2026.

items.title: Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made
items.description: Sugar is a common part of Americans' nutritional intake. Here's how sugar is created, starting with how it's produced on farms. The post Sugar: How it‚Äôs grown and made appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Around 60% of U.S. sugar comes from sugar beets, which are large root crops grown in colder climates like Minnesota, Idaho, and North Dakota. The remaining 40% comes from sugar cane, which is a tall grass grown in tropical climates like Florida and Louisiana.

After the crops are grown and harvested, they undergo similar processing steps to extract the sucrose. This includes separating the juice, filtering, boiling to crystallize the sugar, and centrifuging to remove excess liquid. Sugar beets complete the full refining process at one facility, while sugar cane goes through an additional refining stage at a separate sugar refinery.

By-products of sugar processing include molasses, which is used for animal feed, baking, and pharmaceuticals, as well as the plant residues like beet pulp and cane stalks, which are also used for animal feed and fuel. Even the water used in processing is recycled.

The article notes that sugar is naturally white, and it has an indefinite shelf life since it contains no preservatives. It is a balanced part of the diet, found in many foods and even some medicines. Overall, sugar production demonstrates an efficient and sustainable process from the original plant materials.

items.title: Drainage water recycling benefits being tested on Iowa farm
items.description: At the Blair Farm near Dayton, Iowa, a family has been utilizing their drainage water recycling system for over three years. The project consists of a pond and irrigation setup.
items.summary:
The system captures water from subsurface tile drains during wet periods, stores it in a pond, and then reuses it for irrigation during drought. This was part of a pilot project with the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship.

The Blairs' system stores water in a pond and pumps it through an irrigation pivot on 125 acres. While recent rains have limited their ability to test the full impact, Iowa State data has shown yield increases from the system. Experts like Chris Hay of Hay Water Solutions say the system can provide a 3-inch supplemental water supply during dry summer periods.

An economic analysis by the Environmental Defense Fund found drainage water recycling can boost crop yield income by $130-$146 per acre annually, while saving $10-$20 per acre in operating costs. The practice also provides water quality benefits by reducing nutrient runoff.

However, these systems require a significant upfront investment of $2-$3 million, plus ongoing maintenance. Experts recommend having a pond that can store 4-6 inches of water for the irrigated area. Funding will likely require both private farmer investment and public/outside support.

The Blairs advise other farmers interested in this to seek local help and expertise to plan and implement the system. They are now looking to add features like a fertilizer injection system to further optimize the setup.

items.title: Bayer Crop Science not ready to give up on glyphosate
items.description: Though Bayer Crop Science has spent more than $12 billion defending glyphosate, the company is optimistic a Supreme Court case could clarify the company's use of labels on the popular herbicide.
items.summary:
Glyphosate has been a popular and widely-used herbicide since the 1970s, but has faced controversy since 2015 when the International Agency for Research on Cancer declared it a probable carcinogen. 

Bayer has spent over $12 billion on lawsuits related to glyphosate, and has a 15-11 record in court cases, winning more often than losing. The company is hoping the U.S. Supreme Court will rule in its favor in a case regarding glyphosate labeling.

However, Bayer acknowledges that the constant litigation could make crop protection companies less willing to invest in developing new pesticide chemistries, out of fear of future lawsuits. Bayer may eventually have to exit the glyphosate business, which would be "a bad day" for both the company and U.S. farmers.

The American Sugarbeet Growers Association is working on an amicus brief for the Supreme Court case, as the development of Roundup Ready sugarbeets was a major advance for weed control in that crop.

items.title: Starter Flock Program helps students get involved in the Targhee sheep breed
items.description: In 2023, Annabel Coudron of Marshall, Minnesota, received her starter flock through the U.S. Targhee Sheep Association. Now her breeding program continues to grow.
items.summary:
S. Targhee Sheep Association is helping more young people get started in the livestock industry by providing them with a starter flock of three Targhee ewes, with at least one being a ewe lamb donated by association members. 

In 2023, Annabel Coudron of Marshall, Minnesota received her starter flock through this program and has continued to grow her Targhee sheep flock.

The program aims to make it more accessible for young people to get involved with the Targhee sheep breed. Getting started in the livestock industry can be challenging, but this program provides recipients with a helpful start.

No other specific numbers, prices, statistics, or deadlines were mentioned in the article. The only named individual was Annabel Coudron. The program and Targhee sheep breed were the main organizations/focuses discussed. The location referenced was Marshall, Minnesota. 

The article does not provide much context or discuss any causes or impacts for farmers. However, it does indicate that the Starter Flock Program is intended to make it easier for young people to get involved in raising Targhee sheep, which could have positive impacts by bringing in new producers and helping grow the breed.

No expert quotes were included in this article.

items.title: The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds
items.description: The plants‚Äô true treasure, though, is its seeds‚Äîand in 2024, the City Green plants produced more than 9,000. At a time when conflict in the Middle East has destroyed Palestinian farmland and foodways, these seeds have become a beacon of hope for many. City Green is part of a grassroots network of growers in the […] The post The US Farmers Saving Palestinian Seeds appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: In 2024, the City Green farm in the US produced over 9,000 Palestinian seeds, which have become a symbol of hope for many. The seeds are part of an effort to preserve traditional Palestinian agricultural practices and food ways threatened by the ongoing conflict. The program aims to return the seeds to Palestinian farmers in the future, helping to rebuild their food systems.

items.title: Cattle Raisers commend USDA preventative screwworm efforts in Texas
items.description: FORT WORTH, Texas (February 2, 2026) ‚Äî As part of preventative efforts to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm, United States Department of Agriculture has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon that...
items.summary:
Key Points:

- The USDA has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon extending 50 miles into Texas along the U.S.-Mexico border to prevent the northward spread of New World screwworm.

- The dispersal facility at Moore Air Base is scheduled to receive its first shipment of NWS pupae this week for testing, and is expected to be fully operational within 2-3 weeks.

- Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association (TSCRA) President Carl Ray Polk Jr. welcomes the progress and ongoing collaboration with USDA, but states that until the measures are fully established, keeping the U.S.-Mexico border closed to livestock imports is the responsible course of action to protect livestock and wildlife.

- USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins will keep the border closed, as the threat posed by NWS remains significant and a single incursion could have devastating economic consequences.

- TSCRA, a 148-year-old trade association with over 28,000 members, stands ready to support USDA's efforts to safeguard animal health until the fly can be pushed further south.

items.title: Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX
items.description: AgriLife Extension expert explains how poultry production, pop culture fuel the game-day favorite The post Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
An estimated 1.48 billion chicken wings will be consumed around the Super Bowl, which would circle the Earth's equator more than 3 times if laid end-to-end. 

Wholesale wing prices are $1.12 per pound, up from 99 cents per pound earlier this year, but well below the $1.99 per pound last year, $2.65 in 2024, and $3.80 in 2022. This is due to increased poultry production, even as wings remain a hugely popular Super Bowl snack.

The article cites Texas A&M AgriLife Extension economist David Anderson, who says wings have become a cultural tradition for the Super Bowl, similar to hot dogs on the 4th of July. He notes that wing production is limited by animal physiology, but overall U.S. production this year is estimated at 17.5 billion wings, with about 8.5% consumed just during the Super Bowl.

Anderson says the Super Bowl represents the pinnacle of chicken wing demand each year, and that he will personally be making wings to enjoy for the big game.

items.title: U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow
items.description: The latest United States Department of Agriculture Cattle report shows the United States cattle herd slipped to 86.2 million head on Jan. 1, 2026. The post U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. cattle inventory dipped again in early 2026, continuing a multi-year contraction. As of January 1, 2026, the total U.S. cattle and calves population was 86.2 million head, slightly below the previous year. 

Key statistics:
- Total cattle and calves: 86.2 million head (Jan 1, 2026)
- All cows and heifers that have calved: 37.2 million head
- Beef cows: 27.6 million head (down 1% year-over-year) 
- Milk cows: 9.57 million head (up from last year)
- 2025 calf crop: 32.9 million head (down from prior year)
- Cattle on feed: 13.8 million head (down 3% from 2025)

This report signals a slow start to any nationwide herd rebuild, with beef cow numbers and calf crop down year-over-year. Replacement heifer numbers saw a modest increase, but overall the data points to tight near-term feeder cattle supplies.

For cow-calf producers, the tight supplies mean continued strong prices for calves and bred females, but rebuilding takes time. Stocker and feedlot operators face elevated competition for available feeder cattle. Expansion is likely to be slow and uneven, influenced more by forage conditions, replacement economics, and producer risk appetite than headline prices.
